Posts.Content: bronxville wrote: My 90 year old aunt just received the diagnosis of intracystic papillary carcinoma--with many cancerous nodes.  The surgeon, of course, recommends surgery--removing the front of her breast and, possibly, hormone therapy.  I'm still trying to get details on the cancer (stage, size, number of nodes etc)--but thought I'd ask this wonderful group:  thoughts about treatment, given her age.  She is somewhat confused--an hour after the appointment she couldn't remember it or the diagnosis (a blessing, actually).  I'm concerned that surgery would be too hard on her--but, then again, hormonal therapy doesn't seem that great either.  I've been googling and have found the most recent articles about it--all seem to recommend surgery in every case.   Many thanks in advance for any thoughts you might have Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: 90 yo just diagnosed with IPC--what to do? bronxville Beesie

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2013 04:14PM bronxville wrote: a bit more information:   Two nodes were biopsied (core needle):  both were cancerous, one was 7mm and the other 4mm.  Multiple nodes were noted.  The pathology report calls these encapsulated papillary carcinoma (DCIS) in both cases.
Posts.Title: 90 yo just diagnosed with IPC--what to do? bronxville Beesie

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2013 08:14AM bronxville wrote: Thank you all for your responses.  There is yet another node--6mm, which I found on the path report.  I don't know when her last mammogram was, so the cancer may have been at it for a while--or it may just be aggressive.  But it certainly seems pervasive. Apart from this, physcically my aunt is in reasonably good health--the only medication she takes is Aricept (for memory issues, which are becoming worse and worse--hence my concern about the surgery).  But she is frail, not able to take care of herself or walk very far.  She is now in 24/7 care to ensure that she eats (and eats well), bathes, wears clean clothes, etc. Sounds like the path forward is surgery, with fingers crossed.  I am likely the decision maker, by the way, given her confusion; she won't remember the diagnosis or the decision with any clarity.

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2013 09:00AM bronxville wrote: Christina00 and all, thank you for your comments.  this is what I worry about.  we are meeting the oncologist this Wednesday and I will ask the questions you suggest.  my aunt currently is 'just forgetful'--but she knows herself, her home and me (and her brother, my dad). longer term memories are fine, but shorter term ones don't stick--all signs of early dementia (I've been through that with other relatives).   Will let you know.
